name: "Black Mirror: Bandersnatch" Quiz | Black Mirror | 10 Questions

questions.text: What's the name of the video game company that offers to help Stefan develop "Bandersnatch"?
questions.explanation:
Tuckersoft.

	If the viewer accepts the offer, they receive a lukewarm ending in which "Bandersnatch" is released with little fanfare and to little acclaim.

questions.text: What game is Colin Ritman seen working on when he and Stefan first meet?
questions.explanation:
"Nohzdyve".

	"Nohzdyve" is named for an earlier "Black Mirror" episode, and a playable version of it was made available on a prop Tuckersoft website.

questions.text: Why does five-year-old Stefan refuse to get on the train with his mother?
questions.correct: He doesn't have his stuffed rabbit
options: He's angry with her from an argument
He knows the train will derail
questions.explanation:
He doesn't have his stuffed rabbit.

	The viewer has the option later in the film of re-living that sequence and putting five-year old Stefan on the train, which causes him to suddenly die in the present.

questions.text: Colin and his girlfriend Kitty have a daughter. What is her name?
questions.explanation:
Pearl.

	One of the endings involves Pearl as an adult working for Netflix and setting out to adapt Stefan's life story into an interactive film - that is, a fictionalized version of "Black Mirror: Bandersnatch".

questions.text: Stefan's game, "Bandersnatch", is based on the Lewis Carroll poem of the same name.
questions.explanation:
False.

	While the real-life film is named for an actual game by Imagine Software from 1984 which was never completed (which was, in turn, actually named for the Carroll poem), the fictional game is named for a fictional novel by fictional author Jerome F. Davies.

questions.text: What is the name of the actor that plays Stefan Butler?
questions.explanation:
Fionn Whitehead.

	Whitehead is also known for his starring role in the film "Dunkirk". Will Poulter plays Colin, Craig Parkinson plays Peter Butler, and Jeff Minter plays Jerome F. Davies.

questions.text: What must the viewer influence Stefan to do in order to guarantee the best possible review scores for "Bandersnatch"?
questions.explanation:
Murder his father.

	If Stefan gets away with the murder for long enough, then "Bandersnatch" is released to critical acclaim, though it is recalled when he is caught. It is also possible for Stefan to murder Colin, but this has no direct bearing on the game's success.

questions.text: What is the first choice that a viewer makes at the beginning of the film?
options: Whether or not Stefan starts making "Bandersnatch"
questions.explanation:
What Stefan eats for breakfast.

	Whether Stefan eats the "frooties" or "sugar puffs" has no actual bearing on the film's outcome. The viewer does have the choice of selecting his music later in the film.

questions.text: Which of these songs does not appear in the film?
questions.explanation:
"The Reflex" by Duran Duran.

	"Relax" can be heard from Stefan's alarm clock in the first scene of the film, "Too Shy" plays from the in-store radio in the record shop, and "Making Plans for Nigel" is briefly heard on the radio in Peter's car.

questions.text: One of the film's recurring visual motifs is a symbol representing the potential branching paths of Stefan's story. What earlier "Black Mirror" episode also prominently featured this symbol?
questions.explanation:
"White Bear".

	"White Bear," the second episode of Series 2, features the glyph in the form of a television signal that (supposedly) influences people towards voyeurism.
